subject: Re: [junit] Re: Junit executing tests in separate "clean" processes
msgSnippet: I believe it s hardly the best time of the year to expect a swift answer from the ML... What you should do IMHO is to have a TestCase creating the Object store
messageBody:
I believe it's hardly the best time of the year to expect a swift answer from the ML... What you should do IMHO is to have a TestCase creating the Object store once to validate the Object creation :
    _ empty,
    _ with redundant data's,
    _ with whatever that is specific to your business,
    _ etc...
 
 
I would then create a "factory" to create different TestCase scenarios....
Hu ... ! Sorry forget temporarilly the above line.
I would then create a TestCase to validate that the ObjectStore is in some specific states:
    _ Contains nothing
    _ Contains redundant data's
    _ Contains whatever specific states I can set the Object stores in (Valid & invalid).
 
 
I would then create the TestCase validating the ObjectStore is in these specific states.
Spend some more time to work out the different states the Object may slip into that are right or wrong. Some more senior guys may be willing to give you some advice here.
 
My feeling is that :
    If the project is well coordinated, prepared, ...
    A good sheet of paper & a few days to put in an Excell
    spreadsheet all the things you could then validate
    may be worth (3 to 10 days ???? up to you, guys).
    Keep on coding after 1/2 day, otherwise
 
The you have done the preparation work to make the ObjectStore TestCases.
That created it is time to put all the suite() toghether.
I would  suggest soimething like :
<code>
public class TestObjectStore
{
 
    public static TestSuite suite()
    {
       TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
            suite.addTest(TestCreateObjectStore.suite());
            suite.addTest(TestObjectInStateA.suite());       
            suite.addTest(TestObjectInStateB.suite());       
            suite.addTest(TestObjectInStateC.suite());       
            suite.addTest(TestObjectInStateD.suite());       
            suite.addTest(TestObjectInStateE.suite());       
 
        return suite;
    }
}
</code>
 
I would suggest you to do the following in the different TestCase/s/.
Say in the class :
    TestCreateObjectStore::suite()
 
After you created the TestSuite, while it's still empty do a :
    suite.setName("TestCreateObjectStore - The suite tests this & that....");
in the Swing version you have a much better visual feed back of what is going on.
You may also envisage the fact that you class has more then one static method
returning a TestSuite, you can then :
    suite.setName("TestCreateObjectStore::suiteA() - The suite tests this & that....");
 
This sounds stupid but I found it very usefull to have soem visual feedback in the morning when the test have been runing for half the night to recall what a hell is exactly in the suite...
 
Much regards,
 
Thomas,
 
 
p.s. :
    Wishing you all a trouble free health for the year 2002.
    Anything else you may want request you to work harder,
    probably.... but it's up to you.
